datasets.name: 8b9ee44d
datasets.displayName: Protein Types Distribution with Percentages Chart
queryLines:
-- What types of proteins does this dataset contain? What is their corresponding percentage relative to the existing data and provide a chart for the output.
SELECT
  label,
  COUNT(*) AS count,
  ROUND((COUNT(*) * 100.0 / SUM(COUNT(*)) OVER()), 2) AS percentage
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny
GROUP BY
  label

datasets.displayName: Soluble Protein Molecular Weight Categories Count
queryLines:
SELECT
  CASE
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 0
    AND 9999 THEN '0-9999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 10000
    AND 19999 THEN '10000-19999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 20000
    AND 29999 THEN '20000-29999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 30000
    AND 39999 THEN '30000-39999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 40000
    AND 49999 THEN '40000-49999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 50000
    AND 59999 THEN '50000-59999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 60000
    AND 69999 THEN '60000-69999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 70000
    AND 79999 THEN '70000-79999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 80000
    AND 89999 THEN '80000-89999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight >= 90000 THEN '90000+'
  END AS Weight_Bin,
  COUNT(*) AS Count
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny
WHERE
  label ILIKE '%soluble%'
GROUP BY
  Weight_Bin
ORDER BY
  Weight_Bin

datasets.name: ae25a8db
queryLines:
SELECT
  CASE
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 0
    AND 9999 THEN '0-9999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 10000
    AND 19999 THEN '10000-19999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 20000
    AND 29999 THEN '20000-29999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 30000
    AND 39999 THEN '30000-39999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 40000
    AND 49999 THEN '40000-49999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 50000
    AND 59999 THEN '50000-59999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 60000
    AND 69999 THEN '60000-69999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 70000
    AND 79999 THEN '70000-79999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight BETWEEN 80000
    AND 89999 THEN '80000-89999'
    WHEN Molecular_Weight >= 90000 THEN '90000+'
  END AS Weight_Bin,
  COUNT(*) AS Count
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny
WHERE
  label ILIKE '%membrane%'
GROUP BY
  Weight_Bin
ORDER BY
  Weight_Bin

datasets.name: 9058df3a
queryLines:
SELECT
  label,
  COUNT(*) AS count,
  ROUND((COUNT(*) * 100.0 / SUM(COUNT(*)) OVER()), 2) AS percentage
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny
WHERE
  score > 0.85
GROUP BY
  label

datasets.name: c8c54f3d
datasets.displayName: Organism Distribution of High-Confidence Membrane Proteins
queryLines:
SELECT
  OrganismName,
  -- COUNT(*) AS Count
  COUNT(DISTINCT ProteinName) AS Protein_Count
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny
WHERE
  label ILIKE '%membrane%'
  -- :label ILIKE '%' || :label || '%' --'%membrane%'
  AND score > 0.85
GROUP BY
  OrganismName
ORDER BY
  Protein_Count DESC

datasets.name: 5c0167ed
datasets.displayName: High Confidence Protein Classifications with Organism Insights
queryLines:
SELECT
  p.OrganismName,
  o.Organism_SimpleTerm,
  o.Organism_Definition,
  p.label,
  COUNT(DISTINCT p.ProteinName) AS Protein_Count,
  collect_set(p.ProteinName) AS Distinct_Protein_Names,
  o.SimpleTermDict 
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny p
JOIN
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.tinysample_organism_info_scientificnsimple o 
  ON p.OrganismName = o.OrganismName
WHERE
  p.score > 0.85
GROUP BY
  p.OrganismName,
  o.SimpleTermDict,
  p.label,
  o.Organism_SimpleTerm,
  o.Organism_Definition
ORDER BY
  p.OrganismName,
  p.label

datasets.name: 00ac960e
queryLines:
SELECT
  p.ProteinName,
  COUNT(DISTINCT o.SimpleTermDict) AS TypeCount,
  ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT o.SimpleTermDict) AS SimpleTerms,
  ARRAY_AGG(DISTINCT p.OrganismName) AS OrganismNames
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny p
  JOIN mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.tinysample_organism_info_scientificnsimple o ON p.OrganismName = o.OrganismName
GROUP BY
  p.ProteinName
  -- p.label
HAVING
  COUNT(DISTINCT o.SimpleTermDict) > 1
ORDER BY
  TypeCount DESC

datasets.name: e256576d
datasets.displayName: Comparative Analysis of Protein Types in Select Organisms
queryLines:
-- Comparative Analysis of Protein Types in Select Organisms
SELECT
  p.ProteinName,
  p.label AS ProteinType,
  p.GeneName,
  p.Sequence,
  p.Molecular_Weight,
  p.OrganismName,
  o.Organism_SimpleTerm
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny p
  JOIN mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.tinysample_organism_info_scientificnsimple o 
  ON p.OrganismName = o.OrganismName
-- WHERE
--   (COALESCE(:Organism_SimpleTerm, '') = '' OR o.Organism_SimpleTerm ILIKE '%' || :Organism_SimpleTerm || '%')

datasets.name: 704b4384
datasets.displayName: Organism Counts for High-Confidence Soluble Proteins
queryLines:
SELECT
  OrganismName,
  -- COUNT(*) AS Count
  COUNT(DISTINCT ProteinName) AS Protein_Count
FROM
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny
WHERE
  label ILIKE '%soluble%'
  -- :label ILIKE '%' || :label || '%' 
  AND score > 0.85
GROUP BY
  OrganismName
ORDER BY
  Protein_Count DESC

datasets.name: d26479ea
datasets.displayName: Membrane/Soluble Protein Research Insights and Drug Discovery Potential
queryLines:
SELECT
  OrganismName,
  Organism_SimpleTerm,
  ProteinName,
  mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.get_protein_research_info(ProteinName) AS researchDict,
  researchDict.information AS information,
  researchDict.recent_research AS recent_research,
  researchDict.under_researched_areas AS under_researched_areas,
  ProteinType,
  ProteinClassificationScore
FROM 
(
  SELECT
    p.ProteinName,
    p.label AS ProteinType,
    p.score AS ProteinClassificationScore,
    p.GeneName,
    p.Sequence,
    p.Molecular_Weight,
    p.OrganismName,
    o.Organism_SimpleTerm
  FROM
    mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.proteinclassification_tiny p
    JOIN mmt_demos2.ai_driven_drug_discovery.tinysample_organism_info_scientificNsimple o 
      ON p.OrganismName = o.OrganismName
  WHERE 
    p.score > :ProteinClassificationScore 
    AND o.Organism_SimpleTerm ILIKE '%' || :Organism_SimpleTerm || '%'

lines:
# AI-Driven Drug Discovery Protein Classification Data Exploration AI/BI Genie Space with GenAI-backed AI-Queries to Help Focus Downstream Drug Discovery Efforts

 

#### OVERVIEW: The Life Sciences and Pharmaceutical research and development cycle — which encompasses the discovery, preclinical testing, and early clinical trial phases — is notoriously lengthy, spanning on average \~10-15 years, with a significant portion of drug candidates failing during clinical trials. It is anticipated that the use of Generative AI (GenAI) and Transformer Models will help expedite this process, e.g., by analyzing vast datasets to identify promising drug candidates, predict their efficacy, and optimize molecular structures, leading to faster identification of potential drugs and reducing the time and cost of development. ([ref](https://www.mckinsey.com/industries/life-sciences/our-insights/generative-ai-in-the-pharmaceutical-industry-moving-from-hype-to-reality#/)) #### GOAL: **We provide an example of how GenAI can be leveraged to discover more about protein properties and whether there are candidate proteins that are under-researched in areas that show promise for potential drug discovery**. The corresponding [AI/BI Dashboard](https://docs.databricks.com/en/dashboards/index.html) and when [enabled](https://docs.databricks.com/en/dashboards/index.html#enable-a-genie-space-from-your-dashboard) with a [Genie Space](https://docs.databricks.com/aws/en/dashboards/genie-spaces) allows you to explore the corresponding protein datasets and "***Ask Genie***" (*click button in the middle at the bottom of page*). You can also refer to additional Example Queries (in the repo folder) to *Ask Genie*.

 

---

 

#### **ARCHITECTURE:** The following diagram illustrates the flow of processes involved and the [Databricks Intelligent Platform](https://www.databricks.com/resources/demos/tours/horizontal/introducing-databricks-intelligence-platform) features utilized (in red): ![](https://e2-demo-field-eng.cloud.databricks.com/ajax-api/2.0/fs/files//Volumes/mmt_demos2/ai_driven_drug_discovery/imgs/AI-Drug-Discovery-Page2o.png) --- #### DATA & PROCESSING: To make sense of the *alphabet soup* in our sample of protein sequences, we derive `proteinclassification_tiny`, which contains various columns related to *protein* `classification` (with corresponding `labels` and `scores` as well as protein information), by - i) pre-processing the [FASTA protein sequence data](https://www.uniprot.org/help/downloads) using a **Protein Data Processing** [Delta Live Tables](https://www.databricks.com/product/delta-live-tables) pipeline to help extract protein information e.g. *identifiers*, *sequences*, *names*, *organism information*, *gene names*, *protein existence*, and *molecular weight*; - ii) perform **protein sequence classification** using [a hybrid approach that combines Protein Language Model, e.g., ProtBERT-BFD and a Classifier, e.g., CNN](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37497772/) to provide enhanced identification of [`membrane transport proteins`](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-17216-1) (cf. `water soluble` proteins). We can then sift out protein classification at a suitably high (adjustable) classification confidence threshold
---
Additional **post-processing with GenAI leveraging **[ai-query() ](https://docs.databricks.com/en/sql/language-manual/functions/ai_query.html)yielded the following 2 datasets, which can potentially help in downstream drug discovery processes. - `tinysample_organism_info_scientificNsimple`: contains scientific (`OrganismName`), layman (`Organism_SimpleTerm`), and corresponding `Organism_Definition` information about the different organisms found in the `proteinclassification_tiny` table. It is derived with [ai\_query](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/editor/notebooks/1625373258635024?o=2556758628403379#command/1625373258638832) using the pay-per-token [Foundational Model API](https://docs.databricks.com/en/machine-learning/foundation-models/index.html) `databricks-meta-llama-3-3-70b-instruct` [model endpoint](https://docs.databricks.com/en/machine-learning/model-serving/index.html) and making [batch interferencing](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/editor/notebooks/1625373258635024?o=2556758628403379#command/1625373258638913) with the `ai_query()` registered as a [User Defined Function in Unity Catalog](https://docs.databricks.com/en/udf/unity-catalog.html).
--- - `tinysample_organism_protein_research_info`: contains research information about organisms and their associated proteins, including `recent research` and `under-researched areas` of these proteins that show potential promise for drug discovery. These research insights are derived with the help of [using Azure OpenAI GPT-4o served as an External Model Endpoint](https://docs.databricks.com/aws/en/machine-learning/model-serving/create-foundation-model-endpoints#ext-model-endpoint) and [queried as an External Model using `ai-query()`](https://docs.databricks.com/en/large-language-models/ai-query-external-model.html). For more efficient exploration, the queries for our `tinysample` of proteins are [preprocessed in bulk](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/editor/notebooks/1625373258636712?o=2556758628403379%3Fparent%3Dfolders%2F1625373258638091#command/1625373258641291). These tables are found within the demo workspace [Unity Catalog](https://docs.databricks.com/en/catalogs/index.html) and [Schema](https://docs.databricks.com/en/schemas/index.html#what-is-a-schema): [.ai\_driven\_drug\_discovery](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/explore/data/demos_genie/hls_ai_drug_discovery?o=2556758628403379) and are connected primarily through the `OrganismName`. ---

 

#### DOWNSTREAM EXAMPLE USE CASE : - In section section `3.1` we provide an example of how we can leverage GenAI models (that were trained with real-world research knowledge or fine-tuned to research-relevant publications, e.g., [OpenAI-GPT-4o]((https://openai.com/index/gpt-4o-system-card/) ) to help us to zoom in on under-researched areas for those membrane/soluble proteins that were confidently classified and further investigate their potential therapeutic candidacy.

 

---

 

#### FUTURE USE CASE: It would be helpful to combine the under-researched areas for proteins of interest and visualize their corresponding 3D structural information. By leveraging Deep Learning / GenAI /Transformer models (e.g., [AlphaFold](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-021-03819-2), [RFdiffusion](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-06415-8), including other relevant Life Sciences GenAI/Transformer models, etc.) trained or fine-tuned to predict protein function, structure ([ref](https://deepmind.google/discover/blog/alphafold-reveals-the-structure-of-the-protein-universe/)), as well as potentially simulate new proteins or ways to interact with protein properties ([ref](https://www.ipd.uw.edu/software/)) *in silico* ([ref](https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-024-07601-y)). To this end, an *ongoing* endeavor relates to developing capabilities around `Protein Folding, Single Cell,` and a suite of discovery tools within the [Genesis WorkBench](https://`https://github.com/databricks-industry-solutions/genesis-workbench`) for Life Sciences R&D. ---

lines:
### 2.4 Interactive Exploratory Analyses  using `Organism_SimpleTerm`
- With the help of preprocessing our proteins data using [`databricks-meta-llama-3-1-70b-instruct` within an `ai_query()` to covert `scientific2simple` terms](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/editor/notebooks/1625373258635024?o=2556758628403379) we can more easily use an Organism's  *layman term* to explore its associated `ProteinType`, `GeneName`, `Sequence`, `Molecular_Weight`
- Within the `Organism_SimpleTerm` Search box below: Filter by e.g. `human`, `mouse`, `fly`, `fungus`, `frog`, `zebrafish` to explore an Organism's protein information.

### 2.2 Association between Protein Classification & Distinct Types 
- For each Organism, it would be interesting to find out how many distinct proteins and their corresponding subtypes are associated with sufficiently high classification confidence (scores).
- What is the distribution of molecular weights for water soluble / membrane proteins

### 1.1 General Overview 
- What types of proteins does this dataset contain? 
- What is their corresponding percentage relative to the existing data? 
- Do these change with  proteins classified with high confidences?

### 2.3 Comparative Assessments 
- Understanding diversity of organisms associated with protein shared by more than a single organism can be helpful. 
- We can explore using terms that are similar or part of the `simple_term` in the `SimpleTerms` array.

frame.title: Organism and Associated Frequency of High-Confidence Soluble Proteins

lines: - Frequency counts of soluble / membrane transporter proteins associated with an Organism

### 3.1 Interactively explore under-researched areas for particular proteins of interest        
These EDA discoveries can help yeild actionable insights:    
- We can further use [ai_query](https://docs.databricks.com/en/sql/language-manual/functions/ai_query.html) to leverage the external `azure-openai-gpt-4o` model to assist in [getting information about recent_research and highlight under_researched areas](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/editor/notebooks/1625373258636712?o=2556758628403379#command/1625373258638171) for particular protein of interest with particularly high classification confidence. 
- The `ai_query()` can also be registered to Unity Catalog as a SQL_function and called within a separate query as is done here.

frame.title: Comparative Analysis of Protein Types in Select Organisms
Membrane/Soluble Protein Research Insights and Drug Discovery Potential (Ad-hoc)

lines:
### 3.1.1 *Ad-hoc queries* parameterized by `Organism_SimpleTerm` and desired `ProteinClassificationScore` 
- Use the Options on the RHS to specify Organisms of interest by `Organism_SimpleTerm` and desired `ProteinClassificationScore` thresholds.
- Depending on pay-per-token, concurrency, or endpoint throughput deployment limits the query could take a while. 
- Suggested `Organism_SimpleTerm` to try e.g. `human`, `mouse`, `fly`, `fungus`, `frog`, `zebrafish`, `bird`

### 3.1.2 Pre-computed protein-related research info with UC-registered `get_protein_research_info` SQL_function
- Use the Options below to filter Organisms of interest by `Organism_SimpleTerm` and desired `ProteinClassificationScore` thresholds.
- Because we have [precomputed the research related info.](https://e2-demo-west.cloud.databricks.com/editor/notebooks/1625373258636712?o=2556758628403379#command/1625373258641277) the exploration will be faster than the above example [3.1.1]
- Multiple `Organism_SimpleTerm` can be included

frame.title: Membrane/Soluble Protein Research Insights and Drug Discovery Potential (pre-computed)

lines:
# AI-Driven Drug Discovery --- Note:
This dashboard is formulated in the following format: Section Name - Questions that we look to answer with AI/BI in our data. --- ### Background We utilize the Databricks Intelligence Platform and its AI capabilities to investigate traditionally under-researched areas of study for potential life-saving patient treatments. Pharmaceutical organizations large and small would benefit from infusing their research with data & AI. As you will see in the following sections, not only are clinical results clearer with Databricks, but they are also immediately actionable through the platform.
